ARTICLE 5.02 FIRE CODE*
Sec. 5.02.001 Adopted
In accordance with the International Fire Code (“IFC”), the provisions of the 2015 edition of the International Fire Code, save
and except such portions as are hereinafter deleted, modified, or amended by section 5.02.002 of this article, as well as
amendments recommended by the North Texas Council of Governments are hereby adopted as the fire code of the city, and
declared to be effective within the city limits of said city immediately upon receipt by the city and filing with the city secretary
of one copy of said code and amendments.
Sec. 5.02.002 Specific amendments
The 2015 International Fire Code adopted by this article is amended and changed as follows for Chapter 1, sections 101.1
through 111.4, and chapter 61, are amended as set forth in this section. The remaining “Amendments to the 2015
International Fire Code” are made a part of this article by reference. The city adopts all of the amendments, all of which are
on file in the office of the city secretary.
Chapter 1, section 101.1 is changed to read as follows:
101.1 Title. These regulations shall be known as the fire code of the City of Midlothian, hereinafter referred to as
“this code.”
Chapter 1, section 101.2.1 is changed to read as follows:
101.2.1 Appendices. Provisions in the appendices shall not apply unless specifically adopted. Appendices B, C,
D, E, F and G are adopted with this code.
Chapter 1, section 102.1 #3 is changed to read as follows:
Section 102.1, Construction and design provisions.
3. Existing structures, facilities, and conditions when required in Chapter 11 or in specific sections of this
code.
Chapter 1, section 102.7 add to read as follows:
Section 102.7 Referenced codes and standards. The codes and standards referenced in this code shall be those
that are listed in chapter 80, and such codes and standards shall be considered to be part of the requirements of
this code to the prescribed extent of each such reference and as further regulated in sections 102.7.1 and
102.7.2. If a more current version of the codes and standards listed in chapter 80 is available than when this code
was adopted, the most current version shall be used.
Chapter 1, section 102.13 add to read as follows:
Section 102.13 NFPA 101 Takes Precedence. The entire text of NFPA 101, Code for Safety to Life from Fire in
Buildings and Structures, 2015 edition, published by the National Fire Protection Association, shall take
precedence over the other provisions of this code whenever NFPA 101 mandates a higher level of protection than
required elsewhere in this code, except where it may conflict with state laws.
Chapter 1, section 103.1 is changed to read as follows:
Section 103.1 General. The office of fire marshal is established within the fire department under the direction of
the fire code official. The function of the office of fire marshal shall be the implementation, administration and
enforcement of the provisions of this code.
Chapter 1, section 103.2 is changed to read as follows:
Section 103.2 Appointment. The fire marshal shall be appointed by the fire chief and shall be identified in this
code as the “fire code official.”
Chapter 1, section 103.3 is changed to read as follows:
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 173/598
Section 103.3 Deputies. Employees appointed by the fire chief as fire inspectors or fire investigators shall report to
the fire marshal and be charged with the enforcement of this code under the direction of the fire marshal. All
sworn firefighters of the Midlothian Fire Department are authorized to request compliance with any provision of
this code as adopted. Only those employees of the department who have completed formal training and have
current certification as a fire inspector or peace officer may issue a citation or take enforcement action.
Chapter 1, section 105.3.3 is changed to read as follows:
Section 105.3.3 Occupancy Prohibited before Approval. The building or structure shall not be occupied prior to the
fire code official issuing a permit when required and conducting associated inspections indicating the applicable
provisions of this code have been met.
Chapter 1, section 105.7.19, add to read as follows:
Section 105.7.19 Electronic access control systems. Construction permits are required for the installation or
modification of an electronic access control system, as specified in chapter 10. A separate construction permit is
required for the installation or modification of a fire alarm system that may be connected to the access control
system. Maintenance performed in accordance with this code is not considered a modification and does not
require a permit.
Chapter 1, section 108 is hereby deleted in its entirety.
Chapter 1, section 109.4 is changed to read as follows:
Section 109.4 Violation penalties. Persons who shall violate a provision of this code or shall fail to comply with any
of the requirements thereof, or of a permit or certificate used under provisions of this code, shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of not more than $2,000.00 dollars. Each day a violation continues after due
notice has been served shall be deemed a separate offense. The imposition of one penalty for any violation shall
not excuse the violation or permit it to continue. The application of the above penalty shall not be held to prevent
the enforced removal of prohibited conditions.
Chapter 1, section 109.5 add to read as follows:
Section 109.5 Appeals. Whenever the fire chief or fire code official disapproves an application or refuses to grant
a permit applied for, or when it is claimed the provisions of the code do not apply or the true intent and meaning of
the code have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the applicant may appeal from the decision of the fire

Chapter 1, section 111.4 is changed to read as follows:
Section 111.4 Failure to comply. Any person who shall continue any work after having been served with a stopwork
order, except such work as that person is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition, shall
be liable to a fine of not more than $2,000.00.
Chapter 61, titled Liquefied Petroleum Gases, section 6101.1 to add section numbers 6101.4 through 6101.9, to read as
follows:
6101.4 Adoption of Liquefied Petroleum Gas Safety Rules. The city hereby adopts the Liquefied Petroleum
Gas Safety Rules previously adopted by the Texas Railroad Commission, including any and all future
amendments thereto.
6101.5 Exclusive Regulation. The Liquefied Petroleum Gas Safety Rules adopted under section 6101.4 and the
rules and standards, if any, promulgated with the permission of the Texas Railroad Commission's executive
director shall be the city's exclusive regulations for liquefied petroleum gas.
6101.6 Construction of City Codes. All ordinances, orders, rules, or codes adopted by the city shall be
construed in a manner consistent with section 6101.4 on all matters relating to liquefied petroleum gas.
6101.7 Conflict with City Codes. In the event of conflict between any ordinance, order, rule, or code adopted by
the city and section 6101.4, section 6101.4 shall control.
6101.8 Adoption of Rules, Regulations, Policies, Practices, Procedures, or Standards. City staff shall not
adopt or enforce any rule, regulation, practice, policy, procedure, or standard that conflicts with section 6101.4.
6101.9 Construction Consistent with Texas Railroad Commission. Chapter 61 shall not be construed so as to
conflict with the Texas Railroad Commission's interpretation of the Liquefied Petroleum Gas Safety Rules,
including any and all future amendments thereto.
Sec. 5.02.003 Establishment of limits of districts in which the storage of certain hazardous materials is restricted
or prohibited
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 174/598
(a) The limits referred to in sections 5704.2.9.6.1 and 5706.2.4.4 of the International Fire Code, in which the storage of
class I (flammable) and class II (combustible) liquids in above-ground tanks is prohibited, shall include the area inside the city
limits with the following exceptions:
(1) Nonresidential zoning districts when in compliance with in compliance with city zoning requirements and the
International Fire Code as amended.
(2) Within a planned development district which specifically authorizes such use, and when in compliance with
the International Fire Code as amended.
(3) Temporary storage of diesel fuel in an above-ground tank, for a definite time limit, for fueling off-road
vehicles and equipment at construction or similar work sites when approved by the fire code official and when in
compliance with the International Fire Code as amended.
(4) Facilities owned or under the direct control of a governmental entity where fuel is necessary for the
operation of vehicles, emergency generators or other equipment critical to the infrastructure, and when in
compliance with the International Fire Code as amended.
(5) Agriculture or farm property, in excess of ten acres, where fuel is necessary for the operation of farm
equipment, and when in compliance with the International Fire Code as amended.
(6) Above-ground storage tanks shall be prohibited for retail sale of motor fuels.
(b) The limits referred to in section 5806.2 of the International Fire Code, in which the storage of flammable cryogenic
fluids in stationary containers is prohibited, shall include the area inside the city limits with the following exceptions:
(1) Medium industrial (MI) and heavy industrial (HI) zoning districts when approved by the fire code official, and
in compliance with city zoning requirements and the International Fire Code as amended.
(2) Within a planned development district which specifically authorizes such use, when permitted and approved
by the fire code official and when in compliance with the International Fire Code as amended.
(3) Nonresidential zoning districts when quantities do not exceed the amounts listed in IFC table 105.6.11
Permit Amounts for Cryogenic Fluids, when in compliance with city zoning requirements and the International Fire
Code as amended.

Type of Cryogenic Fluid Inside Building
(gallons)

(gallons)
Flammable More than 1 60
Inert 60 500
Oxidizing (includes oxygen) 10 50
Physical or health hazard not indicated above Any amount Any amount
For SI: 1 gallon = 3.785 L.
(c) The limits referred to in section 6104.2 of the International Fire Code, in which the storage of liquefied petroleum gas
(LP gas) is prohibited for the protection of heavily populated or congested areas, shall include the area inside the city limits
with the following exceptions:
(1) LP gas storage and use shall be in compliance with the International Fire Code as amended, NFPA 58 and
Railroad Commission of Texas requirements and regulations. Where a conflict exists between these requirements
and regulations, the Liquefied Petroleum Gas Safety rules previously adopted by the Texas Railroad Commission,
including any and all future amendments thereto shall apply.

https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 175/598
(2) Nonresidential zoning districts when in compliance with city zoning requirements, the International Fire
Code as amended, NFPA 58 and Railroad Commission of Texas requirements and regulations. Tanks with an
aggregate capacity of 2,000 gallons or more shall require approval of the fire code official.
(3) Residential zoning districts when in compliance with the International Fire Code as amended, NFPA 58 and
Railroad Commission of Texas requirements and regulations.
(4) Within a planned development district which specifically authorizes such use, and when in compliance with
the International Fire Code as amended, NFPA 58 and Railroad Commission of Texas requirements and
regulations.
(5) Existing, nonconforming LP gas installations will be allowed to continue until replaced or modified. Any
replacement and/or modification shall meet current applicable codes, requirements and regulations.
(6) The limits and districts above shall also apply to the storage of compressed natural gas (CNG) and other
alternative fuels.
(d) The limits referred to in section 5601 of the International Fire Code, in which the storage of explosives and blasting
agents is prohibited for the protection of heavily populated or congested areas, shall include the area inside the city limits
with the following exceptions:
(1) Nonresidential zoning districts when permitted and approved by the fire code official, and when in
compliance with city zoning requirements, the International Fire Code as amended, state and federal
requirements.
(2) Within a planned development district which specifically authorizes such use, when permitted and approved
by the fire code official and when in compliance with the International Fire Code as amended, state and federal
requirements.
(e) The limits on storage of hazardous materials in excess of the exempt amounts as defined in the International Fire Code
is prohibited for the protection of heavily populated or congested areas, shall include the area inside the city limits with the
following exceptions:
(1) Nonresidential zoning districts when approved by the fire code official and in compliance with city zoning
requirements and the International Fire Code as amended.
(2) Within a planned development district which specifically authorizes such use, and when in compliance with
the International Fire Code as amended.
(3) Where a conflict exists between local, state or federal requirements and regulations, the more restrictive
provision shall apply.
(Ordinance 2017-40 adopted 5/23/17)
Sec. 5.02.004 Appeals
Whenever the fire chief disapproves an application or refuses to grant a permit applied for, or when it is claimed that the
provisions of the code do not apply or that the true intent and meaning of the code have been misconstrued or wrongly
interpreted, the applicant may appeal from the decision of the fire chief to the city council within 30 days from the date of the
decision appealed. (Ordinance 2012-17 adopted 6/26/12)
Sec. 5.02.005 Penalty
(a) Any violation of the terms of this article and of said code is further declared to be a misdemeanor, and any person
found guilty thereof shall be punishable by a fine of not more than $2,000.00. Each day that the violation continues shall
constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable accordingly. The imposition of one penalty for any violation shall not
excuse the violation or permit it to continue.
(b) The application of the above penalty shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions.
(Ordinance 2017-40 adopted 5/23/17)
ARTICLE 5.03 FIREWORKS*
Sec. 5.03.001 Definitions
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section,
except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 176/598
Fireworks. Any firecrackers, cannon crackers, skyrockets, torpedoes, Roman candles, sparklers, squibs, fire balloons, star
shells, gerbs or any other substance in whatever combination by any designated name intended for use in obtaining visible or
audible pyrotechnic display and shall include all articles or substances within the commonly accepted meaning of fireworks
whether herein specially designated and defined or not.
Person. Includes any natural person, association of persons, partnerships, corporations, agent or officer of a corporation, and
shall also include all warehousemen, common and private carriers, bailees, trustees, receivers, executors and administrators.
Sec. 5.03.002 General prohibition
Except as otherwise specifically provided in this article, it shall be unlawful for any person to manufacture, assemble, store,
transport, receive, keep, sell, offer for sale, use, discharge, cause to be discharged, ignite, detonate, fire or have in their
possession any fireworks of any description. It shall be unlawful for any parent or guardian of any minor child to permit or
allow such minor child to be in violation of this section.
Sec. 5.03.003 Declaration of public nuisance
(a) The presence of any fireworks within the jurisdiction of the city in violation of this article is hereby declared to be a
common and public nuisance. The fire chief is directed and required to seize and cause to be safely destroyed any fireworks
found within the jurisdiction in violation of this article, and any member of the city fire department or any city police officer or
any other duly constituted peace officer is empowered to stop the transportation of and detain any fireworks found being
transported illegally or to close any building where any fireworks are found stored illegally until the fire chief can be notified in
order that such fireworks may be seized and destroyed in accordance with the terms of this section.
(b) Notwithstanding any penal provision of this article, the city attorney is authorized to file suit on behalf of the city or the
fire chief or both for injunctive relief as may be necessary to prevent the unlawful sale, storage, transportation, keeping or use
of fireworks within the jurisdiction of the city and to aid the fire chief in the discharge of his duties and to particularly prevent
any person from interfering with the seizure and destruction of such fireworks, but it shall not be necessary to obtain any
such injunctive relief as a prerequisite to such seizure and destruction.
Sec. 5.03.004 Exceptions
This article shall not apply to:
(1) Signal flares and torpedoes of the type and kind commonly used by any railroad and which signal flares and
torpedoes are received by and stored or transported by any such railroad for use in railroad operation.
(2) Any marine signal flare or rocket of the type and kind commonly carried by a vessel at sea for its own use
and which signal flares or rockets are transported or received and stored for use only as ship's stores.
(3) Signal flares or rockets for military or police use.
(4) Firework displays where the city has issued a permit for such activity to a licensed pyrotechnic.
Sec. 5.03.005 Packaged, unopened fireworks
If fireworks are packaged, unopened fireworks, such fireworks shall not be seized by a peace officer or member of the city
fire department, or anyone else with authority to enforce this article.
Sec. 5.03.006 Affirmative defenses
(a) It shall be an affirmative defense to prosecution under this article for the possession of fireworks if:
(1) The defendant was operating or was a passenger in a motor vehicle that was being operated in a public
place; and
(2) The fireworks were not in the passenger area of the vehicle.
(b) For purposes of subsection (a), the “passenger area” of a motor vehicle means the area of the vehicle designed for the
seating of the operator and the passengers of the vehicle. The term does not include:
(1) A locked glove compartment or similar locked storage area;
(2) The trunk of a vehicle; or
(3) The area behind the last upright seat of a vehicle that does not have a trunk.
(Ordinance 2016-03 adopted 2/23/16)
