ARTICLE 10.04 ESCARPMENT DEVELOPMENT
Sec. 10.04.001 Purpose
The purpose of the escarpment development regulations shall be to promote the following objectives:
(1) To maintain the equilibrium of steep slope areas and control problems of erosion, slumping, and other earth
movement.
(2) To minimize the increased runoff that accompanies the development of slopes, especially during the
construction phase when large tracts of land are disturbed.
(3) To minimize soil erosion by limiting activities that unnaturally expose the subsoils such as cuts, stripping off
topsoil, and major regrading.
(4) To reduce the hazards associated with slope development including flash flooding, landslides, mudslides,
rock falls, sheet, gully, and stream erosion.
(5) To minimize the scarring effects of grading and to protect and retain the natural character of the escarpment.
(6) To provide a factor of safety against unstable slopes or slopes subject to erosion and deterioration in order
to protect human lives and property.
(7) To ensure that development is planned to fit the topography, soils, geology, surface and groundwater
hydrology, and other conditions existing on the proposed site.
(8) To ensure a safe means of ingress and egress for vehicular and pedestrian traffic to and within the slope
areas and to provide access for emergency vehicles necessary to serve the slope areas.
(9) To minimize the high cost of public improvements and maintenance associated with the development of
slopes including the need for increased flood control and storm water management measures, maintenance of
sewer and water infrastructure and roadway maintenance.
(Ordinance 2004-66, sec. 1, adopted 12/7/04)
Sec. 10.04.002 Definitions
For the purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings given
herein. Definitions not expressly prescribed herein are to be determined in accordance with customary usage in municipal
planning and engineering practices.
Austin chalk. A geologic formation which overlies the Eagle Ford shale and is composed of alternating beds of resistant white
chalk and less resistant gray marl. The beds of chalk in outcrop are often fractured and are mainly white to buff in color.
Unweathered surfaces are gray.
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 224/598
Beyond. A distance past measured horizontally from an imaginary line passing vertically through a point.
City engineer. That person or group of persons or consultants or any employee thereof, that has been appointed as city
engineer by the city council.
Civil engineer. A licensed professional engineer trained in general civil engineering principles and licensed in the state.
Crest. That point above the escarpment line where the slope becomes flatter than 4:1.
Developer. Anyone, including a person, partnership, or corporation submitting a plan for development in the escarpment
zone.
Development. Any manmade change to improved or unimproved real estates including, but not limited to grading,
excavating, filling, dumping, removing of vegetation, or erecting of structures.
Eagle Ford shale. A geological formation which is directly overlaid by the Austin chalk. The Eagle Ford is dark gray to black,
soft, fissile to blocky, homogeneous shale which weathers blue-gray to tan.
Engineer. A person duly authorized under the provisions of the Texas Engineering Practice Act, as heretofore or hereafter
amended, to practice the profession of engineering.
Escarpment zone. An environmentally fragile hillslope located immediately above and below the contact between the Austin
chalk and the Eagle Ford shale (escarpment line). The zone is a linear corridor, whose width is described as the distance:
(1) The greater of one hundred twenty-five (125) horizontal feet above the chalk and shale contact, or thirty-five
(35) horizontal feet beyond the crest (that point above the escarpment line where the slope becomes flatter than
4:1); and
(2) The greater of eighty-five (85) horizontal feet below the chalk and shale contact, or thirty-five (35) horizontal
feet beyond the toe (that point below the escarpment line where the slope becomes flatter than 5:1).
Factor of safety. A combination of factors which, when considered together, indicate whether the slope is stable at a slip
surface location. The factor of safety (Fs) is determined using the equation:
Fs = CR L + N tan
Ør
T
Where CR is the residual cohesive strength; Ør is the residual angle of internal friction; L is the length of the slip surface; T is
the total driving force tending to cause the slope failure; and N is the total normal force acting perpendicularly to the slip
surface. The factor of safety should be calculated using this basic equation in conjunction with generally accepted and
recognized state of the art methods for slope stability studies.
Geologist. A person licensed to practice geoscience under the provisions of the Texas Geoscience Practice Act and rules
adopted by the Texas Board of Professional Geoscientist within the discipline of geology.
Geotechnical engineer. A licensed professional engineer trained in geotechnical engineering (soils and rock engineering) and
is licensed in the state.
Grading. Any excavation, filling, clearing or combination thereof.
Person. A natural person, and includes heirs, executors, administrators or assigns, and also includes a firm, partnership, or
corporation, its or their successors or assigns, or the agent of the aforesaid.
Slope. Described as the ratio of tread to rise; 4:1 signifies a land surface that rises one foot vertically over four horizontal feet.
Stable condition. The slope stability factor of safety as required by this article.
Structural engineer. A registered professional engineer, generally civil with special training in structural and foundation design
and registered in the state.
Structure. That which is built or constructed, or any piece of work artificially built up or composed of parts joined together in
some definite manner.
Toe. The point below the escarpment line where the slope becomes flatter than 5:1.
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 225/598
(Ordinance 2004-66, sec. 2, adopted 12/7/04)
Sec. 10.04.003 Escarpment development regulations
(a) Title. This article shall be known as the “escarpment development regulations” for the city.
(b) Applicability. This article applies to land located within the corporate boundaries of the city and within its extraterritorial
jurisdiction.
(c) Development within escarpment zone prohibited. Except as otherwise herein provided, in the escarpment zone, no
construction of structures or other improvements, clearing of natural vegetation, excavation, storage, filling, dumping or other
development shall be allowed.
(d) Development applications. For any parcel of land to be developed that includes a portion of the escarpment zone, all
development applications for such land shall clearly demarcate the boundaries of the escarpment zone and, except as
otherwise provided in the these regulations, shall designate the escarpment zone as a “no build area.” Development may be
clustered on those portions of the development area that are not within the escarpment zone in accordance with section
10.04.004 of these regulations.
(e) Exemptions. The following developments are exempt from the prohibition in this section:
(1) Lawful mineral extraction or stone quarrying and accessory land uses. For land inside city limits, such
activities shall be exempt only if located within a medium or heavy industrial zoning district.
(2) Passive open space.
(f) Exceptions. The following developments shall be allowed in the escarpment zone subject to approval of an escarpment
development plan:
(1) Any lawful land use or development that is located within an area that is a physical remnant of the
escarpment; that is entirely topographically isolated from the continuous escarpment feature due to, for instance,
the construction of roadways bounding the area on more than one side; and, that is less than twenty (20) acres in
area; provided, however, that future development within the escarpment zone for such land shall not include cuts,
or fills resulting in slopes steeper than 6:1 or higher than eight (8) feet.
(2) Utilities located and developed in accordance with section 10.04.008(b)(1).
(3) Roads located and developed in accordance with section 10.04.008(b)(2).
(4) For a structure existing on the effective date of these regulations, the following types of development are
authorized:
(A) Removing less than one hundred (100) square feet of ground cover.
(B) Increasing the size of the structure by less than twenty (20) percent beyond the structure size reported
by the central appraisal district on the effective date of this article.
(C) The applicant may petition the city engineer to waive the slope stability evaluation required by section
10.04.005(c)(3); provided, however that, where alteration of the structure involves modification of any slope
over 6:1 or cuts in the toe area of any shale slope, or cut or fill slopes higher than eight (8) feet, a licensed
civil or geotechnical engineer must evaluate the modification and certify to the city engineer that such a
modification is stable. The city engineer, in his sole discretion, may waive such requirement as part of his
decision on the escarpment development plan in accordance with section 10.04.006.
(5) A development that is not subject to the city's zoning or subdivision regulations by operation of law.
(6) A development for which a petition for relief has been granted by the city council pursuant to section
10.04.010.
(7) Trails and related recreational improvements.
(8) Railroad main line or auxiliary line and necessary rights-of-way.
(g) Development plan. Prior to the acceptance for filing of any application for approval of a development listed in
subsection (f) above, including but not limited to an application for a planned development, plat, site plan, grading permit or
building permit, an escarpment development plan that meets the requirements of this article must be approved by the city. If
an escarpment development plan has been previously approved for the property, the applicant may rely upon such plan only
if the plan addresses the nature and extent of the development proposed.
(Ordinance 2004-66, sec. 3, adopted 12/7/04)
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 226/598
Sec. 10.04.004 Cluster development plan for planned development (PD) zoning district
(a) Applicability and purpose. For land to be developed within city limits or, for land in the city's extraterritorial jurisdiction,
pursuant to a development agreement, that contains any portion of the escarpment zone, the property owner may submit an
application for approval of a cluster development plan. The purpose of a cluster development plan shall authorize the use of
residential density standards in substitution for minimum lot size standards for residential uses, or to authorize increased
impervious cover, lot coverage, or building heights for nonresidential uses within an approved planned development (PD)
zoning district.
(b) Effect. Approval of a cluster development plan authorizes the property owner to submit a plat application for the
property consistent with the approved cluster development plan and the regulations of the PD zoning district.
(c) Concentration of density or intensity of use. Pursuant to the adoption of a PD zoning district, the city may allow
development on that portion of the property not within the escarpment zone up to the maximum residential density or the
maximum intensity of use, for nonresidential development, that otherwise could be developed on the entire property, less any
part of the land within the escarpment zone that is developed pursuant to an exemption or exception in section 10.04.003.
(d) Other applications. A cluster development plan shall be submitted together with any proposed escarpment
development plan, and may be submitted with a plat application, provided that the cluster development plan application and
accompanying planned development ordinance are adopted first.
(e) Application requirements. In addition to the application requirements for a PD zoning district, an application for approval
of a cluster development plan shall contain the following information and documents:
(1) All documents and information required for a concept plan pursuant to the city's planned development
district regulations.
(2) For proposed developments consisting of single-family detached dwellings or duplex units, a detailed plan of
development illustrating the following specific matters:
(A) All environmental features and protected areas, including all areas included within the escarpment
zone;
(B) Layout of residential lots showing density and lot sizes;
(C) A description of how open space serving the development shall be satisfied for the phase of
development subject to the cluster development plan, including any proposed dedications of open space to
the public or to a private maintenance organization;
(D) A chart demonstrating compliance with equivalent residential density standards for the zoning district
in which the property is located.
(f) Processing of application and decision. An application for a cluster development plan shall be processed in the same
manner as an application for a planned development zoning district or significant change to a planned development, in
accordance with section 6.1 of the city's zoning ordinance (Ord. No. 89-13 as amended).
(g) Criteria for approval. The planning and zoning commission in recommending, or the city council, in taking action on the
cluster development plan application, shall apply the following factors:
(1) The cluster development plan meets the standards for residential density, as set forth in the city's adopted
comprehensive plan.
(2) The cluster development plan is consistent with the applicable planned development (PD) district
regulations.
(3) The cluster development plan conforms to the escarpment regulations.
(4) The cluster development plan contains sufficient buffering to assure compatibility with adjacent uses and the
character of the neighborhood.
(h) Expiration. Cluster development plans shall expire in accordance with the rules for expiration of the PD zoning district.
(Ordinance 2004-66, sec. 4, adopted 12/7/04)
Sec. 10.04.005 Application for escarpment development plan
(a) Application. The following shall submit an escarpment development plan to the city.
(1) Any person desiring to develop property in the escarpment zone pursuant to an exception provided under
section 10.04.003 shall submit an escarpment development plan to the city. The application may be submitted
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 227/598
simultaneous with another application for development in the escarpment zone, and where allowed by other
provisions of the city, may be processed with such other application, provided that the application for the
escarpment development plan is decided first. The city may require that information pertaining to the escarpment
development plan be included in other development applications within the escarpment zone.
(2) Any person desiring to develop within the drainage area above the escarpment (i.e. anyone who will
discharge surface water over the slope of the escarpment) shall submit an escarpment development plan to the
city. In this case, the application shall demonstrate compliance with the standards in section 10.04.008(a)(6), (a)
(8), (a)(13) and (a)(14).
(b) Pre-application conference. Upon request of a developer, a pre-application conference between the developer and
representatives from the city shall be conducted. The purpose of this meeting shall be to inform the developer as to what
information he shall be required to submit for evaluation by the various city departments and the number of copies which
must be submitted. Additionally, a tentative timetable for the submission of all requested information shall be determined.
(c) Contents of application. An escarpment development plan shall include the following documents:
(1) General requirements. The following general information, maps and drawings:
(A) The name and address of the developer and a statement of the developer's interest in the proposed
development.
(B) The name and address of any person holding or claiming an ownership interest in the property if
different from subsection (A) above.
(C) The name and address of the person preparing the items submitted.
(D) A general vicinity map of the proposed site on a scale of 1"=2000'.
(E) A brief description of the proposed development.
(F) A map outlining the proposed development site within the escarpment zone and showing the contours
of the property at a minimum of two-foot intervals with details of the terrain and area drainage on a minimum
horizontal scale of 1"=100' and a vertical exaggeration of 4:1.
(G) A drawing which shows cross sections for every one hundred (100) linear feet of the property on a
minimum scale of 1" = 50'.
(2) Site geology report. A geology report showing the geologic profile of the site shall be prepared and sealed
by a geologist, and shall include a discussion of the topography, soils, site geology including boring locations,
descriptions of borings, (including percent core recovery, rock quality designation, and description of
discontinuities), drilling methods used and depth and location of samples taken for laboratory analysis.
(A) The depth of the Austin Chalk–Eagle Ford Shale contact shall be specified on the boring logs. The
position of the water table shall be shown if applicable. Methods used to infer future position of the
groundwater table shall be described in relation to long term slope stability.
(B) The geologist shall construct a geologic map of the site showing the location of the escarpment line,
the area of outcropping Austin Chalk and Eagle Ford Shale. Methods used to delineate the escarpment line
shall be stated and calculations shown.
(C) The report shall indicate the results of a minimum of three borings which penetrate through the Austin
Chalk–Eagle Ford Shale contact. The maximum spacing between borings shall be 1,000 feet and all borings
must be within 1000 feet of the escarpment line. All boring locations shall be surveyed and presented on the
map which shows the location of the escarpment line. This map shall have 2 foot contours and be at a scale
of 1" = 100'. Conclusions and recommendations covering the geology of the site with regard to development
shall also be addressed.
(3) Slope stability evaluation. A slope stability analysis shall be submitted showing slope stability calculations
for each new structure proposed to be erected within the escarpment zone and the results of engineering tests
performed on samples of representative soil and rock within the site to adequately describe the existing geological
conditions.
(A) All tests and calculations for new development within the escarpment zone shall be performed under
supervision and sealed by a geotechnical engineer. The structural foundations for all new developments
shall be designed and sealed by a structural engineer.
(B) Calculations of slope stability analysis will indicate shape of slip surface(s), location of slip surface(s),
assumptions concerning the location of the water table, assumptions made regarding the density, and shear
strength used in the calculations and corresponding factor(s) of safety.
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 228/598
(4) Design report. Recommendations shall be prepared by a licensed civil or geotechnical engineer detailing
design criteria for corrective measures, when necessary; and opinions and recommendations covering the
adequacy and safety of the site for development and long term maintenance of the escarpment slopes, as well as
conclusions and recommendations for grading procedures. The design report shall include the following:
(A) A table showing the results of engineering tests including, but not limited to, direct shear strength
tests, unconfined compression tests, moisture content and bulk density tests, Atterberg limits and swell
tests.
(B) Engineered drawings of each structure to be placed within the escarpment zone, such as foundations,
retaining walls, drainage outfalls, sewer and water lines, utility lines, transmission towers, roadways etc. at
an appropriate scale as determined by the city engineer, together with any preventative measures.
(5) Grading plan. A grading plan prepared by a civil engineer shall be submitted satisfying the city's adopted
grading and excavation permit ordinance requirements. The grading plan shall incorporate recommendations from
the design report.
(A) This plan will also include the pre-development and post-development hydrology/hydraulic analysis
indicating the runoff and flow and velocities over the site for the 1, 2, 5, 10, 25, 50 and 100-year storm
frequencies.
(B) The analysis shall show the proposed drainage plan which shall include the detailed plans for all
surface and subsurface drainage devices, walls, cribbing, dams, storm sewer outfall design and other
structural or protective devices to be constructed with or as part of the proposed work together with a map
showing the location of each.
(6) Soil erosion plan. A soil erosion control plan prepared and sealed by a licensed civil engineer or licensed
geoscientist complying with the city's adopted regulations and NCTCOG's Storm Water Quality Best Management
Practices for Construction Activities. The plan shall include, but is not limited to, the following information:
(A) Type of soil cover (as mapped by the U.S. National Resource Conservation Service).
(B) Erodability of mapped soils (K factor) and computation of anticipated erosion losses for the area using
RUSLE (Revised Universal Soil Loss Equation) and appropriate delivery ratios for pre-construction,
construction, and post-development phases.
(C) Existing and proposed development.
(D) A timing schedule indicating anticipated starting and completion dates of the development sequence
and time of exposure of each area prior to completion of control measures.
(E) Measures to be taken to prevent or control erosion and sedimentation of existing soils during and after
construction.
(F) A detailed site plan at a scale of 1" = 100 feet which shows existing vegetative patterns and proposed
vegetation removal and replanting strategy within the escarpment zone.
(7) Restoration plan. An estimate prepared by a civil engineer of the cost to restore that portion of the
development site which is in the escarpment zone to a stable condition also shall be submitted. Requited site
restoration shall be completed prior to any building permit issuance.
(Ordinance 2004-66, sec. 5, adopted 12/7/04)
Sec. 10.04.006 Escarpment development plan review and approval
(a) Distribution and review. Upon submission to the city of a complete application for approval of an escarpment
development plan, the city engineer shall forward copies of the plan to the planning director, as well as any other interested
departments for their review. Outside consultants may be employed to review all or portions of the escarpment development
plan where such is deemed necessary by the city engineer. Where a consultant is utilized, the city engineer shall inform the
applicant of the consultant's name and address.
(b) City departments. After reviewing all information, reports and plans of the escarpment development plan, the various
city departments shall submit their evaluations in writing to the city engineer.
(c) Decision by city engineer. The city engineer shall review all information, reports and plans submitted by the developer
together with the city department evaluations to determine whether the escarpment development plan meets the standards
set forth in section 10.04.008. The city engineer shall have twenty (20) working days from the date the complete escarpment
development plan application is submitted to review the escarpment development plan and either approve it as submitted,
approve it with conditions, or deny it and provide the developer with a list of written objections. This time period may be
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 229/598
extended for ten (10) working days upon written notice to the applicant by the city engineer stating the reason for the
extension.
(d) Acceptance of conditions. If the escarpment development plan is approved with conditions pursuant to section
10.04.008, the developer shall have ten (10) working days to file a notice of acceptance of these conditions, or the plan shall
be deemed denied. If the applicant accepts the conditions, he shall submit a plan revised in accordance with these conditions
to the city engineer within twenty (20) working days of the city engineer's approval unless the applicant gives the city
engineer written notice of a need for additional time.
(e) Amended plan. If the city engineer denies the escarpment development plan application, he shall provide the applicant
with a list of written objections. The developer will then have an opportunity to amend the plan. In all cases, the developer
shall have fifteen (15) working days to respond to the written objections from the city engineer. If the developer does not
respond to any written objections and receive approval for an amended plan, the plan shall be deemed denied.
(f) Action on amended plan. The city engineer shall have fifteen (15) working days to review the amended plan and either
approve it, approve it with conditions, or submit additional written objections, or the plan shall be deemed approved. This time
period for response to the amended plan may also be extended for fifteen (15) working days upon written notice to the
applicant by the city engineer stating the reason for the extension.
(Ordinance 2004-66, sec. 6, adopted 12/7/04)
Sec. 10.04.007 Appeals to commission
(a) Appeal.
(1) An applicant may appeal the city engineer's decision to deny or conditionally approve the escarpment
development plan, or if the city engineer fails to act within the time periods prescribed in section 10.04.006.
(2) An adverse party may appeal the city engineer's decision to approve or conditionally approve the
escarpment development plan.
(3) A written notice stating the grounds for appeal shall be filed with the city secretary within fifteen (15) days
from the date the city engineer takes action on the application, or, if the city engineer fails to take action within
prescribed time limits, within (15) days from the end of such period. The city secretary shall forward this notice to
the planning and zoning commission.
(b) Hearing and record. The planning and zoning commission shall set a time and place for a hearing on the appeal. Prior
to the hearing, all materials previously filed with the city engineer by the applicant and all written reports by city departments
and the city engineer as well as the city engineer's findings and objections shall be submitted to the commission. The
commission may retain consultants to assist it in deciding the appeal.
(c) Decision. Upon closing of the hearing, no additional information or evidence may be submitted to the commission by
any party. The commission shall reach its decision within fourteen (14) days of closing the hearing. The commission may act
to:
(1) Approve the escarpment development plan as submitted by the developer;
(2) Approve the developer's escarpment development plan with conditions in accordance with section
10.04.008; or
(3) Deny the developer's escarpment development plan for specified reasons.
(d) Acceptance of conditions. If the escarpment development plan is approved with conditions by the commission, the
applicant shall have ten (10) days to file a notice of acceptance of these conditions, or the plan shall be deemed denied. If
the applicant accepts the conditions, he shall submit plans revised in accordance with these conditions to the city engineer
within thirty (30) days of the commission's action, unless the applicant gives the city engineer written notice of a need for
additional time. If the applicant takes no action within thirty (30) days of the commission's decision, the escarpment
development plan shall be deemed denied.
(Ordinance 2004-66, sec. 7, adopted 12/7/04)
Sec. 10.04.008 Criteria and conditions
(a) Approval standards. The city engineer, or the planning and zoning commission on appeal, shall take action on the
escarpment development plan in accordance with the following general standards:
(1) No structure, cut or fill shall be constructed or placed where the slope stability factor of safety is less than
1.5.
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 230/598
(2) Development shall be fitted to the topography, soils, geology, and surface and groundwater hydrology of the
site.
(3) Natural vegetation shall be retained and protected wherever possible.
(4) When land is exposed during development, the exposure shall be kept to the shortest practical period of
time and to as small an area as possible at any one time.
(5) Sediment basins or other approved installations shall be installed and maintained to remove sediment from
runoff waters from land undergoing development.
(6) Discharge of storm water over the escarpment face shall be minimized with no concentrations or velocities
greater than that in the existing state or less than 3 fps.
(7) Collection and routing shall be implemented through the use of stilling basins, retention basins or flow
retardant vegetation. No unapproved ponding of water in the escarpment zone shall be allowed.
(8) Provisions shall be made to effectively accommodate all increased runoff caused by changed soil and
surface conditions during and after development.
(9) Temporary vegetation and/or mulching or other approved best management practice shall be used to protect
areas exposed during development.
(10) Erosion control planning and methods shall be in conformance with NCTCOG's Storm Water Quality Best
Management Practices for Construction Activities.
(11) Grading shall be planned so as to have the least disturbances on the area's natural topography,
watercourse, vegetation, and wildlife. Grading shall not be allowed within the 100 year floodplain boundaries of
watercourses with the exception of those approved by the city engineer.
(12) Topsoil shall be stockpiled and respread on areas where vegetation will be grown after the grading is
completed, and methods to ensure erosion protection and maintenance of these areas until vegetation is
established shall be implemented.
(13) The increased runoff caused by changed soil and surface conditions during and after development must be
maintained at pre-development rates and the increased runoff must be controlled within the approved drainage
facilities.
(14) Stream channel velocities shall not exceed 5 feet per second in the shale.
(15) Cuts for grading or utility installation in the toe area of the slope shall not be allowed, unless the application
conclusively demonstrates that over-steepening due to excavation of the toe will not result in progressive slope
failure.
(b) Standards applicable to particular uses. In addition to the standards in subsection (a), the following criteria apply to
particular types of development within the escarpment zone:
(1) Utility lines. Utility lines shall not be installed parallel to the slope face within the escarpment zone. Where
practicable, utilities shall be installed in a common trench to reduce the number of trench excavations. Roads and
rights-of-way shall be designed to allow flexible offsets for utility trenches. Separate cuts for utilities across the
escarpment shall be discouraged. Utility pipe joints shall be designed for surficial soil creep and expansive soil
conditions. Cut-off walls or seepage collars to decrease downslope seepage along trenches shall be installed to
limit migration of water and slope failures. Steep water and sewer lines situated in grades of 20% or steeper shall
be securely anchored with concrete collars immediately downslope from each bell and keyed into the trenchwalls.
Low density cement stabilized backfill shall be required along utility cutes in such areas of the escarpment.
(2) Roads. The number of roadway cuts through the escarpment zone shall be minimized in order to reduce
long term road maintenance costs as well as disruption of natural corridors.
(c) Conditions. The city engineer, the commission on appeal, or the city council on a petition for relief, may attach such
conditions to the approval of an escarpment development plan as are necessary to carry out the intent and purposes of these
escarpment development regulations, based upon the approval standards set forth in subsection (a) or (b) above. Conditions
may include but are not necessarily limited to, restrictions on the types, and intensity of uses, or the design of structures, that
may be placed on the development site; restrictions on the placement or design of roadway and drainage improvements and
utilities for the development site; structural improvements to assure the stability of the site or of individual lots or
improvements; preservation of existing vegetation or revegetation of the development site; and temporary improvements to
insure the stability of the development site during construction.
(Ordinance 2004-66, sec. 8, adopted 12/7/04)
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 231/598
Sec. 10.04.009 Approved escarpment development plan
(a) Performance bond. Upon approval of an escarpment development plan, the city engineer shall require the submission
of a performance bond in an amount equal to one hundred (100) percent of the estimated cost to restore that portion of the
development site which is in the escarpment zone to a stable condition. The performance bond shall not represent a
guarantee of safety or the cost to restore structures, buildings, etc., above, below, or in the escarpment zone. In determining
the amount of the required bond, the cost estimate submitted by the developer may be used, but it is not binding. This bond
shall be in the form of a corporate surety bond or a letter of credit from a bank or savings and loan association acceptable to
the city. Upon satisfactory completion of all work described in the escarpment development plan within the escarpment zone,
the bond shall be surrendered. The bond must be submitted and approved by the city engineer before any work may begin at
the site.
(b) Single-family dwelling exception. Construction of individual single-family dwellings shall be excluded from these
bonding requirements. Any developer activity which damages property and is not repaired is subject to repair by the city. A
lien shall be filed on the property for all cost incurred by the city.
(c) Action on subdivision plat. If the escarpment development plan was submitted with a request for approval of a plat, the
city engineer shall notify the planning and zoning commission of the grant of approval of the escarpment development plan.
The commission's action on the plat shall be consistent with the approved escarpment development plan.
(d) Action on building permit. If the escarpment development plan was submitted with a request for a building permit, the
approved plan shall become a part of the building plans and may not be changed or altered in any way except upon written
approval of the city engineer.
(e) Lapse. If actual development does not begin on the site within two (2) years of approval of the escarpment
development plan, the escarpment development plan shall expire, unless the developer submits a report to the city engineer
signed by a geotechnical engineer stating that there has been no change in existing conditions which requires amending the
approved plans, in which case the escarpment development plan may be extended for a period not to exceed one additional
year.
(f) Maintenance bond. A maintenance bond which is required for the subdivision ordinance shall include the costs of any
improvements required by this article.
(g) Assurances. Before final approval of an escarpment development plan, the applicant is required to submit an affidavit
signed and sealed by a licensed professional engineer in the state stating as follows: “I (engineer's name) do
hereby state that I and/or trained personnel under my direct supervision, made sufficient site visits to the (project)
during construction to confirm that the construction was done in general compliance with the plans and specifications. The
necessary laboratory testing required for quality control was performed by (testing lab). I have reviewed all
testing reports, and there are no deficiencies. After the completion of the construction, I personally made a final inspection of
(project) on (date) and all known deficiencies have been corrected.”
(Ordinance 2004-66, sec. 9, adopted 12/7/04)
Sec. 10.04.010 Petition for relief
(a) Petition. A property owner may petition the city council in writing for relief under these escarpment development
regulations in the following circumstances:
(1) The property owner is prohibited from developing within the escarpment zone by these regulations, and his
application for a cluster development plan has been denied or approved with conditions which he does not accept;
(2) The property owner's application for an escarpment development plan allowed by these regulations has
been denied or conditionally approved by the planning and zoning commission, or the application is deemed
denied under these regulations.
(b) Grounds for relief. The petition shall set forth the grounds for relief in detail, and must assert that the operation of these
regulations or the denial or conditions imposed on an application hereunder deprives the property owner of a vested right to
develop his land free from one or more requirements contained in these escarpment development regulations, or that the
effect of the regulations or action by the city on his application deprives him of the economically viable use of his property.
The petition also shall identify the provisions of the regulations or the conditions imposed on the application that should be
removed or relaxed in order to provide relief.
(c) Procedures. The petition for relief must be submitted within fifteen (15) days of the date the city takes final action on the
application for the cluster development plan or escarpment development plan to the city secretary. The city secretary shall
forward this notice to the city council and set a date for a public hearing before the council. Prior to the hearing all materials
previously filed with the city engineer by the developer, all written reports by city departments, the city engineer, and the
appeals board, as well as the city engineer's and commission's findings and objections shall be submitted to the city council.
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 232/598
(d) Standards. In deciding whether to grant relief to the applicant based upon the petition, the city council shall take into
consideration the following:
(1) The prospective harm to the public's health, safety and welfare if such relief is granted;
(2) The extent to which development within the escarpment zone on the proposed development site would
constitute public or private nuisance;
(3) The extent to which relief can be provided through redesign of the project;
(4) The types and numbers of development permits for the project previously obtained by the applicant;
(5) Any construction of structures in reasonable reliance on prior development permits;
(6) The installation of infrastructure or issuance of bonds to finance such infrastructure to serve development
within the escarpment zone;
(7) The total expenditures made in connection with the proposed development I reliance on prior development
permits, and whether such expenditures were made in connection with the entire project or a particular portion or
phase;
(8) Any fees reasonably paid in connection with the project;
(9) Any representation made by the city concerning the project and reasonably relied upon to the detriment of
the applicant.
(e) Decision. Upon closing of the hearing, no additional information or evidence may be submitted to the city council by
any party. The city council shall reach its decision within fourteen (14) days of closing the hearing. The city council may:
(1) Approve or modify the decision of the planning and zoning commission on the application for a cluster
development plan or escarpment development plan, in order to avoid a deprivation of a vested right or the
economically viable use of the property. If such action is taken, the city council shall modify conditions or authorize
variation from standards contained in this chapter only to the extent necessary to prevent the deprivation of
economic use, and may impose additional conditions to achieve such objectives.
(2) Deny the petition for relief for specified reasons.
(f) Expiration of approval. Where the city council grants relief on the petition, all claims pertaining to vested rights to
development which is authorized thereby shall be deemed waived, forfeited and void, if the following events occur:
(1) An application for a development permit is not filed within thirty (30) days of the city council's granting of
such relief; or
(2) Substantial construction pursuant to such development permit, including site grading and the pouring of
permanent foundations, is not completed within one year of the issuance of a building permit, or as otherwise
provided by the city council in granting relief.
(g) Resubmission. If the cluster development plan or escarpment development plan is approved with conditions by the city
council on the petition for relief, the property owner shall have ten (10) days to file a notice of acceptance of these conditions,
or the plan shall be deemed denied. If the property owner accepts the conditions, he shall submit plans revised in
accordance with these conditions to the city engineer written notice of a need for additional time.
(Ordinance 2004-66, sec. 10, adopted 12/7/04)
Sec. 10.04.011 Enforcement
(a) Any person conducting development in the escarpment zone without an escarpment development plan, or any person
owning, leasing or occupying property in the escarpment zone on which development is being conducted without an
escarpment development plan shall be considered to be in violation of this article.
(b) Each day that development is conducted in the escarpment zone without an escarpment development plan shall be
considered a separate violation.
(c) Any person who shall violate any provision of this article or shall fail to comply, therewith or with any requirement
thereof, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be liable to a fine, and upon conviction of any such violation in an
amount to not exceed that allowed by state law.
(Ordinance 2004-66, sec. 11, adopted 12/7/04)
Sec. 10.04.012 Relationship to other regulations
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 233/598
The escarpment development regulations established by this article are additional and supplemental to, and not in
substitution of any other requirements imposed by the city on the development of land. Such development regulations are
intended to be consistent with and to further the policies of the city's adopted comprehensive plan, subdivision ordinance,
zoning ordinance, building codes, grading ordinance, and all other city policies, ordinances and resolutions by which the city
seeks to manage the development of land and protect the environment. In the case of any conflict between these
escarpment regulations and any other city regulation, the more strict regulation shall apply. (Ordinance 2004-66, sec. 12,
adopted 12/7/04)
Sec. 10.04.013 Penalty
Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any of the provisions of this article or who shall fail to comply with any
provision hereof within the corporate limits of the city shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction shall be subject
to a fine provided in section 1.01.009, and each day that such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense and
shall be punishable accordingly. (Ordinance 2004-66, sec. 13, adopted 12/7/04)
CHAPTER 11
TAXATION
ARTICLE 11.01 GENERAL PROVISIONS*
(Reserved)
ARTICLE 11.02 AD VALOREM TAXES†
Division 1. Generally
Sec. 11.02.001 Additional penalty for delinquency
(a) Whenever any accounts for delinquent taxes owed the city are given to its tax attorney for collection, on or after July 1
of the year they become delinquent, the city shall be entitled to, and shall collect, an additional penalty of fifteen (15) percent
of the delinquent taxes and penalty (including any interest owed) due on each delinquent property at the time of collection,
either before or after suit and/or foreclosure sale as provided by V.T.C.A., Tax Code section 33.07.
(b) In addition to the collection expenses provided for in subsection (a) of this section, the city shall be entitled to collect
the actual expenses incurred by the city in providing all data and information as to the name, identity, and location of
necessary parties and the legal description of property necessary to the filing of any suit for delinquent taxes.
(1990 Code, sec. 12-31)
State law reference–Imposition of penalty for collection of delinquent taxes, V.T.C.A., Tax Code, secs. 33.01, 33.07, 33.08.
Sec. 11.02.002 Goods in transit
Goods in transit, personal property, as defined by the amendments to Texas Tax Code, section 11.253 under Senate Bill 1,
shall be, and are hereby declared to be, taxable by the city for tax year 2012 and for every year thereafter, all as provided for
and in accordance with Texas Tax Code, section 11.253. (Ordinance 2011-35 adopted 10/11/11)
State law reference–Tax exemption for goods in transit, V.T.C.A., Tax Code, sec. 11.253.
Secs. 11.02.003–11.02.030 Reserved
Division 2. Exemptions
Sec. 11.02.031 Elderly and disabled veterans
(a) Seventy thousand dollars ($70,000.00) of the assessed taxable value of all residential homesteads of married and
unmarried persons sixty-five (65) years or older, male or female, including those living alone, shall be exempt from ad
valorem taxes levied in the tax year by the city.
(b) That disabled veterans be entitled to an exemption from taxation based upon the degree of their disability as provided
by section 11.22 of the Texas Property Tax Code.

Commencing with tax year 2018 and subsequent years thereafter, a limitation on the total amount of taxes that may be

ARTICLE 11.03 SALES AND USE TAXES*
Sec. 11.03.001 Continuation of tax on gas and electricity
(a) The city does hereby elect to continue to impose a one-percent city sales tax on residential use of gas and electricity.
(b) Residential use, for the purposes of this section, is defined as use in a family dwelling, a multifamily apartment, a
housing complex or building or portion of a building occupied as a home or residence.
(1990 Code, secs. 12-96, 12-97)
State law reference–Authority of municipality to impose tax on sales of gas and electricity, V.T.C.A., Tax Code, sec. 321.105.
Sec. 11.03.002 Telecommunications service
(a) A tax is hereby authorized on all telecommunications services sold within the city. For the purposes of this section, the
sale of telecommunications services is consummated at the location of the telephone or other telecommunications device
from which the call or other communication originates. If the point of origin cannot be determined, the sale is consummated at
the address to which the call or other communication is billed.
(b) The rate of the tax imposed by this section shall be the same as the rate imposed by the city for all other local sales
and use taxes as authorized by the legislature of the state.
(c) The city secretary shall forward to the comptroller of the state by United States registered mail a copy of Ordinance
2002-58 along with a copy of the minutes of the city council's vote and discussion on Ordinance 2002-58.
(d) This section shall become effective as of January 1, 2003.
(Ordinance 2002-58, sec. 1 (12-98), adopted 11/26/02)
State law reference–Authority of municipality to impose tax on the sale of telecommunications services, V.T.C.A., Tax Code, sec.
321.210.
ARTICLE 11.04 HOTEL OCCUPANCY TAX*
Sec. 11.04.001 Definitions
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section,
except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
Consideration. The cost of the room in a hotel only if the room is one ordinarily used for sleeping and shall not include the
cost of any food served or personal services rendered to the occupant of such room not related to the cleaning and readying
of such room for occupancy.
(1990 Code, sec. 12-71)
Hotel. A building in which members of the public obtain sleeping accommodations for consideration. The term includes a
hotel, motel, tourist home, tourist house, tourist court, lodginghouse, inn, roominghouse, or bed and breakfast. The term does
not include:
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 235/598
(1) A hospital, sanitarium, or nursing home; or
(2) A dormitory or other housing facility owned or leased and operated by an institution of higher education or a
private or independent institution of higher education as those terms are defined by section 61.003, Education
Code, used by the institution for the purpose of providing sleeping accommodations for persons engaged in an
educational program or activity at the institution.
(Ordinance adopting Code)
Occupancy. The use or possession or the right to the use or possession of any room, space or sleeping facility in a hotel if
the room is one ordinarily used for sleeping and if the occupant's use, possession or right to use or possession extends for a
period of less than thirty (30) days.
Person. An individual, company, corporation or association owning, operating, managing, or controlling any hotel.
(1990 Code, sec. 12-71)
Sec. 11.04.002 Levy; rate
There is hereby levied a tax upon the cost of occupancy of any sleeping room furnished by any hotel where the cost of
occupancy is at the rate of two dollars ($2.00) or more per day, such tax to be equal to seven (7) percent of the consideration
paid by the occupant of such room, space or facility to such hotel, exclusive of other occupancy taxes imposed by other
governmental agencies. Such seven-percent hotel occupancy tax shall be levied on hotels both inside the city limits and in
the extraterritorial jurisdiction of the city. Any revenues from the taxes derived hereunder from the consideration paid by an
occupant of the sleeping room to the hotel may only be used for the purposes described in V.T.C.A., Tax Code, section
351.001. (1990 Code, sec. 12-72; Ordinance adopting Code)
Sec. 11.04.003 Exemptions
Persons who are exempt from payment of the hotel occupancy tax imposed under this article are the persons described in
V.T.C.A., Tax Code, section 351.006, under the conditions imposed by said section 351.006. (Ordinance adopting Code)
Sec. 11.04.004 Portion of proceeds used for advertising, etc.
Inasmuch as the tax levied under this article is seven (7) percent of the total consideration paid for the occupancy of hotel
rooms, the city shall reserve a portion of the tax revenue equal to at least one (1) percent of the costs of the occupancy of
hotel rooms for the purpose of advertising and conducting solicitation programs to acquaint potential users with public
meeting and convention facilities, and for promotion of tourism and advertising of the city and its vicinity either by the city or
through contract with persons or organizations selected by the city. (1990 Code, sec. 12-73)
Sec. 11.04.005 Reports
Every person required to collect the tax levied by this article shall file a report with the city treasurer by the last day of the
month following each quarterly period. The report shall include the consideration paid for all room or sleeping space
occupancies in the preceding calendar quarter, the amount of taxes collected on such occupancies, and any other
information the city treasurer may reasonably require. A copy of the state hotel and motel tax report may be used to meet this
reporting requirement. A copy of the state report and check payable to the city for the taxes due shall be forwarded to the city
treasurer. (1990 Code, sec. 12-74)
Sec. 11.04.006 Rules and regulations
The city treasurer shall have the power to make such rules and regulations as are necessary to effectively collect the tax
levied in this article and shall, upon reasonable notice, have access to books and records necessary to enable the city
treasurer to determine the correctness of any report filed as required by this article and the amount of taxes due under the
provisions of this article. (1990 Code, sec. 12-75)
Sec. 11.04.007 Reimbursement for collection
The person required to file a report under this article may deduct and withhold from the taxes otherwise due to the city on the
quarterly return, as reimbursement for the cost of collecting the tax, one (1) percent of the amount of the tax due as shown on
the report. If taxes due under this article are not paid to the city within the time required or if the person required to file a
report fails to file the report when due, the person forfeits the claim to reimbursement that could have been taken if the tax
had been paid or the report filed when due. (1990 Code, sec. 12-76)
Sec. 11.04.008 Penalties for violations
If any person shall fail to file a report as required in this article or shall fail to pay the tax imposed under this article, when
such report or payment is due, such person shall forfeit five (5) percent of the amount due as a penalty, and after the first
thirty (30) days shall forfeit an additional five (5) percent of such tax, provided that the penalty shall never be less than one

https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 236/598
dollar ($1.00). Delinquent taxes shall draw interest at the rate of ten (10) percent per annum beginning sixty (60) days from
the date due. (1990 Code, sec. 12-77)

CHAPTER 12
TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES
ARTICLE 12.01 GENERAL PROVISIONS*
Sec. 12.01.001 Ordinances saved from repeal
Ordinances designating or establishing traffic regulations for specific streets or parts of streets, including stop and yield
intersections, speed limits, one-way streets, parking and loading zones, through streets, etc., have not been included in this
chapter but are specifically saved from repeal and are in full force and effect the same as if they were included in this chapter
in their entirety. Such ordinances are on file in the city secretary's office. (Ordinance adopting Code)
Sec. 12.01.002 Structural prohibitions
No person shall place, construct or erect any pole or structure with a hockey, soccer or basketball goal, rim, hoop or other
device affixed thereto designed or intended to be used for or readily adaptable for athletic or sporting purposes, or any other
obstruction, upon, along, or across any public right-of-way or other public easement in the city. (Ordinance 2005-17, sec. 3,
adopted 5/10/05)
ARTICLE 12.02 TRAFFIC-CONTROL DEVICES†
Sec. 12.02.001 Manual and specifications adopted
All traffic-control devices, including signs, signals and markings on pavement and/or curb, installed or used for the purpose of
directing and controlling traffic within the city shall conform with the manual and specifications for traffic-control devices
adopted by the state transportation commission. All existing traffic-control devices and those erected in the future by the city
being consistent with the manual and specifications, state law and this section shall be official traffic-control devices. (1990
Code, sec. 13-26; Ordinance adopting Code)
Sec. 12.02.002 Ratification of existing devices
All lawfully erected traffic-control signs, signals, markings and devices in existence on the effective date of the adoption of
this code are ratified and confirmed and continued in full force and effect until changed by order of the city council.
(Ordinance adopting Code)
Sec. 12.02.003 Unauthorized installation
It is unlawful for any person other than the city engineer and the police chief, acting pursuant to an ordinance of the city, to
install or cause to be installed any signal, sign or device purporting to direct the use of the streets or the activities on those
streets of pedestrians, vehicles, motor vehicles, or animals, excluding speed control devices. (1990 Code, sec. 13-28;
Ordinance 98-18, sec. 1, 3/10/98; Ordinance 2002-50, sec. 1, 11/12/02)
Sec. 12.02.004 Evidence of authorized installation
Proof in any prosecution for a violation of this article or any traffic ordinance of the city that any traffic-control device, sign,
signal or marking was actually in place on any street shall constitute prima facie evidence that the same was installed by the
city engineer and the police chief pursuant to the authority of this article and of the ordinance directing the installation of such
device, signal or marking. (1990 Code, sec. 13-29; Ordinance 98-18, sec. 1, 3/10/98; Ordinance 2002-50, sec. 1, 11/12/02)
Sec. 12.02.005 Authority and duty in the regulation of traffic
In the event of construction on or adjacent to any street or highway, the city engineer or designated representative is
authorized to conduct an engineering and traffic investigation to determine if the maximum lawful prima facie speed limit

https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 237/598
established by this code should be temporarily reduced in order to preserve and protect the public safety. If the city engineer
determines that such speed limit should be reduced, they shall enter a written finding and order to that effect and, upon
approval of that order in writing by the city manager or their designated representative, the city engineer or designee shall
have the authority to erect temporary official traffic-control devices. These devices shall be erected in proper position and
sufficiently legible to be seen by an ordinarily observant person prior to any enforcement action against an alleged violator.
The finding and order of the city engineer and city manager or their designated representatives shall estimate the length of
time for which such temporary speed limit shall be in effect and, if necessary, an additional order in writing shall be entered in

written order, nor in any event longer than is necessary to complete the construction for which the speed limit was ordered. A
certified copy of the order shall be admissible in evidence in municipal court to establish the authority of such temporary
speed limit, and it is hereby determined and declared that any such temporary speed limit found and ordered in accordance
with this section shall be the speed which is reasonable and prudent under the conditions and having regard to the actual
and potential hazards then existing, and any violation of such temporary speed limit shall be considered a violation of this
code. (Ordinance 2008-43 adopted 9/23/08)
ARTICLE 12.03 PARKING, STOPPING AND STANDING*
Sec. 12.03.001 Definitions
For the purposes of this article, the following terms shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them:
Corner lot. A lot or property located at the intersection or confluence of two or more streets such that public street rights-ofway
are directly adjacent to at least two contiguous sides of the lot.
Driveway. The continuous improved surface which provides ingress and egress from a garage, carport or off-street parking
area to an adjacent street, alley or other improved public way.
Front yard. A yard across the full width of a lot extending from the street to the largest required setback of either the required,
established, platted building line or projected front yard. Setbacks shall be measured from the front property line. Each street
frontage shall be considered a front yard except that in one- and two-family zoning districts, the extra frontage yards may be
considered a side or rear yard if there are no other front yards projecting along that same block face.
Improved surface. A continuous surface for the movement, parking or storage of a vehicle designed and constructed for all
weather conditions including the use of gravel, paving blocks, asphalt, concrete or other materials as approved by the city
engineer.
Large vehicle. Any vehicle, towable device or combination thereof excluding recreational vehicles (RVs) that measures more
than 25 feet in length or more than eight and one-half (8'-6") feet in height or that exceeds a manufacturer's gross vehicle
weight rating of 10,000 pounds.
Motor vehicle. Any vehicle smaller than the defined large vehicle.
Old town (OT-Midlothian). That portion of the city known as the original town of Midlothian plat areas and for the purposes of
this article, generally described as the boundaries between 1st Street to North 14th Street and West Avenue A to Walter
Stephenson Road, excluding the area around South 3rd, as depicted in the map below:
Original Town Map
(for the purposes of this article)
